participants.participant: Sir Fred Goodwin, Group Chief Executive
Johnny Cameron, Chief Executive, Corporate Markets

plist.p: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our Annual Results presentation. 2007 was quite a year in banking, but it's been a very good year for RBS. Our businesses are performing very well and delivered a record group operating profit of ₤10.3 billion, up 9%. Adjusted earnings per share were up 18% to 78.7 and the board increased the dividend by 10% to ₤33.2 for the full year. So, very good operating performance. In addition to that, we acquired ABN AMRO together with our friends in Fortis and Santander. Now you'll hear a good deal more about that and what it means for the group going forward from Fred and Johnny Cameron.
But first I would like to hand over to Guy to take you through the results in more detail. Guy.

Thank you. Thank you very much Tom, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. 2007 was a very strong year for the Group. Operating profit at £10.282 billion is up 9%. The profit attributable to shareholders rose by 18% to just over £7.3 billion. Adjusted earnings per share rose by a similar amount. Our return on equity increased to 19.9% and our Tier 1 capital ratio at the end of the year was 7.3%. These results incorporate many strong performances across many of our businesses.

They also incorporate the 76 days that we acquired ABN and they incorporate a number of moving parts and what I would like to do is run through the results on RBS excluding ABN on a business as usual basis, look at some of the unusual items, which occurred throughout 2007, talk a little bit about the ABN business that we acquired and then hand over to Fred, who will talk about the enlarged Group, the revised organizational structure and the outlook.

Group income grew by 3% in 2007, principally driven by a 7% rise in net interest income as margins across the group stabilized or in some cases even widened. Our costs were brought down by one percentage point and our cost income ratio fell, for I think, a record low of 40.7% down 1.4 points.

We saw a stable corporate credit environment. We saw declining UK impairments. We saw a slight up tick in impairments in the United States, but overall our risk elements in lending fell from 1.57 to 1.49% and credit costs declined 1% to £1.86 billion. As a result, our profits rose by £884 million or 9% to just under £10.3 billion.

Once again, I think, these results demonstrated the strength, the flexibility and diversity of the business model that we operate. There were good performances within all of our divisions and there were some particularly strong collective performances in UK corporate banking in the retail division and wealth management and in Ulster.

And I'll now walk through each of those divisions. Many areas of our Global Banking & Markets division had a very good year indeed. We saw a 33% up lift in fees on origination and distribution of loans and bonds. We saw a 67% growth in our combined rates and currencies business. We saw almost doubling of income and profits in Asia, a 39% year-over-year improvement in Europe, building on a long succession of a growth in these markets.

We also took advantage of very favorable market conditions to realize a number of gains and disposed a variety of assets throughout the year. However, as you can see from the headline numbers these results were held back by the second-half write-downs in the credit markets, absent the extraordinary effect of the gains and the write-downs, the underlying business in global banking grew 10%.

As we highlighted at the trading statement, we took of number of marks related to credit markets principally in the second half of the year. We remain comfortable with the markets -- marks that we took at the trading statement and we remain so. However, in the light and of the weaker credit profile of some of the monoline financial guarantors that we had exposure to we announced this morning an additional £450 million write-down to – our exposures to these counter parties.

So if you take the £950 million number that we talked about at the trading statement and add about £150 million or so for the first half write-downs that were incorporated in the results that we shared with you back in August and the £456 million as of today, you see total write-downs to the credit markets netted out at £1.6 billion. If you take the costs associated with these deals out of the profit line, it impacted our profits by about £1.1 billion.

On the positive side the gain on Southern Water, the sale on leaseback, and the sale of our small equity holdings in both London Stock Exchange and MasterCard realized gains of around 1.4 billion and again stripping out the costs and also allowing for some goodwill payments that we've made out of the group centre over the course of the year have added about £1.1 billion to our profit. The net effect of these gains and these write-downs impacted the Group operating profit by a positive £24 million.

The slide behind illustrates now the combined exposure that we had as of the end of the year to these instruments and say they were marked at the time of the trading statement and we remain comfortable with the RBS marks that were applied to that portfolio.

In the year-end review, we looked at the ABN high grade super senior CDO and we took an additional 10 percentage points write-down to that marking down from 90 to 80 and that's incorporated in the weighted average price that you see in the top right hand corner of this page.
Let's just say the aggregate ABN combined year exposure to both our CDO exposures, all sub-prime inventory, any residual securitization activity, and our leveraged finance book.

Just heading back into the divisions, UK Corporate Banking had a great year. Profits grew 11% to almost £2 billion. It is the leading corporate and commercial bank in the UK. It is relationship driven, top rated for customer service by its clients and gaining market share. We grew income by 8% or just over £3.75 billion. We are continuing to invest in the future. You can see from the impairment cost declined very careful management of the risk profile and a business, which once again has delivered the results.

We saw a very good performance in our UK Retail Banking division, again leading customer satisfaction scores, almost 1 million new accounts added in 2007, the leading position in UK current accounts. The cautious approach to lending, which Gordon has talked to you about over the last year or two, has led to a 9% decline in impairments on a year-over-year basis. On the other hand, we've seen a very strong growth in savings and investments with income there up 14%. Our bank assurance, annualized premium equivalents grew 28%. Our deposit base grew by 11%, again exceeding growth in loans in this particular area. We kept a tight reign on costs and saw improving margins coming through in the second half. Momentum in this business feels strong into 2008.

Wealth Management saw income rise by 16% to just over £1 billion and profits rise by 30% to just over £400 million led by growth in our UK private banking and in Asia. Very good mix of business here around 70% of our income derived from banking activities and about 30% comes from investment activities. Assets under management grew 24% over the year. We continue to invest in physical distribution here in the UK and abroad and we continue to be recruiting private bankers with a growth rate of 12% on a year-over-year basis.

It's a similar and quite familiar story now of growth in investment in Ulster Bank, income up 15% to £1.3 billion. Profits up 22% to over £500 million; good growth on both sides of the balance sheet. Deposits up 17%, mortgage lending up 17% and we're starting to see real momentum coming through on the corporate side of the business there with good growth in capital markets in conjunction with GBM colleagues in Europe and around the world. And good growth in business lending, we saw 29% year-over-year increase in volume. Credit metrics, as evidenced by flat credit costs, remained very strong.

The Citizens group, I think you would describe it as a resilient performance against a weaker economic backdrop. After a number of years of declines, net interest margins started to widen in 2007, that has led to net interest income growing by about 3 percentage points on fairly modest balance sheet growth. We saw a good progress in our corporate and commercial expansion with lending up 13%. We kept a very tight reign on costs. And profits before impairment lines were up over 5 percentage points. However, I think it's the standout number on the page from historic lows of around 30 basis points. We started to see some rise in impairment costs in 2007 and partly it was due to planned growth in the corporate lending book and in part, of course, related to the weaker housing market and also in the fourth quarter in some considerable part to build our reserves in that business. Overall, the portfolio remains very high quality. Retail customer FICO scores on average are above 700.

In Insurance, it really was actually a very good result overshadowed by the floods. A very good underlying improvements to the business performance really built around three areas; firstly, much tighter control on costs and improving productivity; secondly, a sharp differentiation between our own brand distribution channels being managed for growth and our partnership distribution channels being managed for profitability and over the course of the year we have exited some of these partner distribution channels.

And the third element is built around improved risk selection moving away from volumes at any price in what is a very competitive market to looking at segments of the market, which offer more attractive risk and return characteristics. This will be evidenced, although distorted by the flood numbers, our net claims, excluding the floods actually fell by 7 percentage points and I think -- I dare make the pun, weather permitting the outlook for 2008 seems somewhat brighter for this business.

And Manufacturing, I think is testament to our operating model and almost flat costs, certainly support cost were flat on a year-over-year basis. We continue to invest in technology and in property that led to a 1% overall rise, and I think very much underpinned the growth that we saw right across the Group and a major factor contributing to the 1.4% decline in our cost income ratio that I mentioned earlier.

At the Group Center, net of goodwill payments, we were the beneficiary of roughly £500 million worth of the previously announced gains, the sale and leaseback of some properties, the London Stock Exchange and Master Card and the fair value adjustments to the carrying value of our own debt. The Group Center also benefited from the receipt of about a £60 million dividend from the Bank of China and some slightly reduced pension funding costs as our pension fund moved into surplus.

For the ABN AMRO businesses that we acquired, an operating profit of around €640 million for the year off income of just under €7 billion. It's kind of in line with where we thought they were been, probably slightly ahead of the equivalent number last year. We saw some year-on-year improvements in equities, in rates, in currencies, in some of the local markets activities, we saw a 7% rise in transaction banking. Our international retail customer base grew by about 12 percentage points, but as you have seen from the very earlier slides, an 86% cost-income ratio is something with which we are not familiar at RBS and not surprisingly in the time of ownership we have identified some additional synergies, which Fred will talk about later.

We ended the year with a balance sheet of £609 billion worth of risk-weighted assets, a core Tier 1 ratio of 4.5%, the Tier 1 as I mentioned earlier is 7.3 and total capital of 11.2% consistent with previous guidance that we had given. Our return on equity rose to 19.9%.

And in summary, before handing over, I think 2007 now categorizes a year of strong organic growth for the Group, improved operating leverage, declining credit costs, increased returns and enhanced opportunity and to talk to you about some of those opportunities, I'll hand over to Fred. Thank you.

Thanks Guy. Good morning, everyone. A lot of moving parts, a lot to absorb and please see something of an accounting fest and in my section this morning I am trying to strike a balance between bringing some context to those and to what's been going on in the group and to give a sense of how we see the future, but also to leave plenty of time for questions at the end because I know that you all have a lot of things that you want to ask. So I am erroring in favor of the latter, so I am going to try and move through the gears here pretty quickly, I am happy to go back over any of this and will pick up any questions at the end. But a few things I think would be helpful, one, starting off with a housekeeping point about the Group structure.

I know that many of you don't like it when change the Group structure, it doesn't make life easier for your models and your ability to predict what we are doing. To be honest, it doesn't make our life very much easier either and which is why we've stuck pretty much with a Group structure for the last 7 or 8 years now. It served us well, but we have along the way made one or two minor amendments to it, but we've tried to stick pretty much with this. And the world's moved on though and our business is very different now from where it was then and obviously the acquisition of ABN AMRO does make a big difference so with a little reluctance we have moved from historic model to a new model, which of course causes the numbers to change.

The new model – I am going to go through it in any great detail, simply reflecting the fact that we have some genuinely global businesses now. We recognized that a couple of years ago we set out GBM, Global Banking & Markets simplistically as the business that deals with OSEAN growing companies regardless of financial institutions, regardless of where geographically they are based.

We now have our very significant Global Transactions Services business, which Johnny will talk a little bit about in a minute. Regional markets are all of our other businesses, where the focus on managing them will continue to be regional. RBS Insurance comes through this unscathed and we continue with the very successful manufacturing model, which will cover our global operations.

I'm not going to go through this slide at all, this is a wiring diagram on net impact on which you will need to begin to make sense of the numbers that we published at the back of the company announcement today. It's restating all of our comparatives along the new lines for 2006 and 2007. We will be working with Richard O'Connor and this team will be happy to work with you to help walk you -- to talk you through this and we will be doing some investor days later in the piece to walk you through, I think all together more importantly the actual businesses, which sit beneath these divisions.

So, that's all I was going to say on that for now. I want just to give you a quick sense of all these sorts of metrics and dynamics in these business units. They are very big business units moving at some pace as you will see from the slide. Most of the Global Transaction Services, our payments business, our merchant acquiring business will be one of the top three, four in the world and that business punched in just over 1.6 billion profit during 2007. I think a business we have always been in but it's been kind of hidden and obscured and the numbers the ABN were one of the top global participants in that particular activity.

Acquisition of ABN AMRO, again in the interest of time I am not going to go through all of the clocks and dials about how very single thing is going. I am very happy to answer questions and as I know Mark would be and others. But, I think the main news is that our view of all of the businesses is positive view. The view we had of the ABN businesses has been confirmed. We have a very good engagement with the regulator in the Netherlands and indeed elsewhere and with the staff councils, the works council, they're very good, important relationships in both cases.

And as we've gone around -- and you'll see bits of this over time that as we've looked at the mechanics of separating out some of parts of business, some of them just the practicalities and the economics of separating some of businesses in some of the countries just don't make sense. You would have seen – it was just before the year-end we sold global client Brazil to Santander and transferred it to them for about €750 million, there will be one or two other little things as we go forward, but nothing drastic. And of course, one of the key activities has been validating our business plans, our transition plans and of course the synergies.

Looking at ABN AMRO, it's probably worth just reminding ourselves as everyone is in a 71, €72 billion figure has been much syndicated and socialized, but it's worth coming back to how we see this from the RBS perspective because we – although we bought 38% of the business actually we got – the part of what we bought was cash, the sale proceeds of the net of the net assets. So our share consideration is just over €16 billion.

Our share price came down from the point at which the offer was struck. When the deal was completed, we made the sale of Brazil. So, it brings us around to an acquisition price of about £10 billion, which was made of about 25% equity, the rest in cash. Probably just worth having those numbers in your minds, I think that stopping someone in the street would probably have guessed a rather higher number there for what our acquisition cost of ABN AMRO actually was.

The synergies – the cost synergies probably the most – the easiest piece to imagine and get your mind around. We've gone in and we've validated the estimates. And remember these estimates were prepared from outside the business, they would prepare them and then we published them and they're actually lower than the equivalent numbers that were mentioned by Barclays. And there is no – there haven't been any eureka moments here -- there haven't been gosh we discovered a whole new thing. I think that's probably quite good news, in fact what we've seen are developments of the themes, which were identified initially and an ability to put much more precise figures on them.

But part of the joy from our point of view is they're all moving rather mundane. Even in the purchasing arena, I can't think of any more mundane purchasing synergy than stationery where we were able to procure stationery at 20% less than ABN AMRO and so it reads across IT, not all 20% in every case, but in hardware, software and a variety of other areas. So nothing in here that's a silver bullet eureka type additional synergy, just routine mundane run of the mill synergies, which I think – as I find deeply reassuring. Also I think deeply reassuring and in sharp contrast to the equivalent situation in NatWest there isn't a single huge solution in here.

You'll remember the many happy hours we spent debating the IT issues around NatWest and so much hung on our ability to make the IT integration work. And here you can pretty much take the synergies and divide them into the total and come away with a sense that there are lots and lots of small things. And so they don't all have to go well and it's unlikely that they would all go well. So, we're confident enough in that number to increase the target today, based on all the work that we've performed.

The revenue synergy side, always a slightly more nebulous concept I grant you. For the big -- the most obvious piece here is that at the time of the takeover you'll remember we said we didn't make any assumptions about synergies in the retail businesses. We couldn't get our mind very well around the international retail businesses -- the big retail businesses, which there were in Asia. We can do that now and you'll see a big part of the synergy comes simply from that including a synergy where there wasn't one before. Again, considerable confidence around our ability to deliver these synergies and again no big sliver individuals, sliver bullet items, no eureka moments since the bid.

And somewhat abstracted and theoretical nevertheless, but just had we known no synergies at the time those are how the model matrix would have looked taking what were already very attractive and I think making them even more attractive. Somewhere abstract I grant you.

Commonsense check in all of this, so supposing we did achieve those synergies, did it take us to a ridiculous place? Well, actually no -- you could argue it'd take us to a not all that impressive of place by achieving all of those synergies and sticking them on top of the 2007 numbers, the underlying 2007 numbers. We only get a 61% cost-income ratio, which doesn't feel to be something that we would be bragging about, but at least from a point of view of validating the synergies, I think, it's a good as test -- as good a crosscheck as any.

Much wish we could talk about ABN AMRO and as I said I'm very happy to take questions, but in the interest of time we'll just move through it. The outlook and predicting the future is a topic, you know, I always try and avoid and in fact do avoid, but it is quite reasonable and rational that we should all be thinking about the future arguably more so then ever at this particular juncture. What do you want to look at? Well, historically I've looked at these numbers, I'm not going to spend a lot of time looking at these this morning other than to point out the obvious perhaps that you know things do tend to turn out better than you think and this time last year the view in economic growth – actually the consensuses view in economic growth turned out to be understated everywhere except in United States.

So it is the forecast of 2008, as we've progressed through 2007 have moved – it's difficult to argue with the fact that we haven't moved in one direction and pulled the blankets over our head and go away and say things are slowing down next year, there's no business to be done. I think there's growth happening and in that respect I think we have moved forward quite a lot in the last year.

We now have presence in nine of the ten top contributors to GDP growth -- is moved on quite a way. We now have the ABN businesses in China, with 1200 people on our payroll in China, in addition to the relationship in joint venture, we're adding on business units in North America there obviously, but we had clearly a critical mass in the organic growth over the last 7, 8 years, ditto France.

We have in India has split those numbers maybe 50/50 between the back office ECS function, which ABN AMRO had and our front facing profit generating, profit making customer facing franchise in India, which we're very excited about. And so GDP growth can slowdown and for the rate of growth that we had, but there is still lots of growth are there to go after and we're well represented in the economies, where A) there is growth and B) there are significantly sized economies.
Another thought is that all the GDP growth that took place last year, we're active in 91% of -- we have 91% of that available to ourselves by being in the countries where it took place.

Again, all pretty abstract stuff, you can have your own views about economic forecasts for GDP growth and I haven't attached too much significance to them other than the fact that they're there and they still forecast growth in the coming year. And much better lens though I think is to start to look at our individual businesses. I'm not going to go through all of these. I think in many respects the prospects for next year are sort of linear for lots of these businesses. But an area where I don't think for a moment that it could be described as linear is in a new global markets division. Those are numbers on the -- as we stated to follow the organization structure I introduced a moment or so ago. Anyway I'll just invite Johnny to come forward and talk -- give you just a little bit of sense of the outlook viewed through the global markets lines.

Well, good morning everyone. Like Fred, I will also try to move at a reasonable pace. People often say in markets like this there are lots of opportunities and the thing we have is that we have our opportunity already, which is ABN. Also very well – it's good in times like this to have a project and I think I can say with confidence that my colleagues in GBM are a great deal busier than some of our colleagues in other banks at the moment. We have a lot to do and we're getting on with it.

It's an important opportunity integrating ABN. We've told you before what we're trying to do here. We're trying to exploit the larger customer franchise, the greater geographic reach and a much broader product range. This is a progression of what we were doing in RBS before, but there is no doubt that the ABN acquisition accelerates that very, very significantly. And in particular and something perhaps we haven't highlighted enough yet, is our position now as a real leader in global transaction services. I'll talk about that a little bit more.
The point I want to leave you with is that we've got much greater diversification at -- in 2008 than we had in 2007 and that leaves us better placed to face the future.

Let me just run through these points in very briefly. This is the slide of Fred and others used in the acquisition. You've all seen it hundreds of times, I think, it just makes the points that ABN and RBS are coming together in the global banking and markets arena. We are much stronger by product. We are much stronger in geographic terms and we're much stronger in client terms, in terms of the enlarged customer franchise. You've seen it a lot before I'm just putting it up because I want to remind you that is the anchor for what we are trying to do in GBM.

Global Transaction Services is worth dwelling on a little bit more. This is a slide you haven't seen before. What we are doing in Global Transaction Services is we are bringing together what RBS had, in particular a leading position in merchant acquiring in the UK and in Continental Europe and to a lesser extent through RBS Lynk in America. Taking those merchant acquiring businesses we are taking the domestic money transmission businesses for corporates in Britain and in America. And we are adding that to ABN's very strong position international cash management and trade finance around the world and this is trading a global leader in a business, which has got a very high barriers to entry. It is something that people don't go out and build today. You just can't build a network in 53 countries. You can't put in the IT infrastructure. So we are in a position where we are the top three or four in the world, as Fred says, in this business and a business that others can't easily get into.

It's a stable business. It's largely deposit income and fee income. It's also very useful as an entry point for GBM products. So it's part of the enlarged customer franchise that we have to work with. We believe that there is far more opportunity that has yet been grasped to sell GBM products into transaction banking class, transaction services clients across the world.

So this is an important new development. It is a new thing for RBS to have a business like this and I've got high hopes of its synergistic benefits within global transaction services. The synergies are bringing together the RBS bits of it with the ABN bits of it. And there are also important synergies as I said a moment ago with global banking and markets.

Just an update on market position, as you bring the two bits of GBM together, in 2007 the figures I showed you first were the original slides so they were 2006 numbers. In 2007 in the old debt lead table – the lead table I think everyone agrees is the best global table that is all bonds, all loans, all currencies, all countries, where do we rank as an underwriter?

Putting ABN and RBS together in 2007, we were number three. That's a fantastic position, a fantastic position demonstrating the power of the franchise. And, of course, it's not just the income you earn off of underwriting bonds and loans that is the driver for so much of our other income in derivatives and foreign exchange and so on.

The other three tables on this chart just remind you where we are in terms of customers again updated for 2007. And the point is that we are in the top five in all the three main regions, I haven't put UK up because obviously, we're number one by distance in the UK. But in continental Europe, we're number one. We're number five in America, number five in Asia, excluding Japan. So this is why we can claim to be the one of the top -- maybe the top one or two banks, corporate banks in the world today, again a demonstration of the power of the franchise that we now have to work with.

Just turning to the performance of the business in 2007 and looking at – just to emphasize this -underlying income as we've defined it and since 2007. You can see here – there are two key points to bring out immediately. Diversity, that we have a diverse range of products and diversity of growth. So you can see as we mentioned already that rates and currencies had a very strong year in 2007 in both banks, particularly in RBS perhaps.

You not surprisingly can see that the securitization asset-backed and CDO's quite significantly down in terms of income. And then the bottom two that rose worth highlighting are underlying asset portfolio management and global transaction services, which are basically stable businesses that's where all the net interest income lies in asset portfolio management and global transaction services as I have emphasized as deposit income and fee income.

They are very large stable, but growing businesses in the case of global transactions services. So I hope you find that a helpful description of the business we have going into 2008. And of course, in 2008, there is the same slide but you can see at the bottom there, commodities. We still expect to close on acquiring our share of Sempra Commodities on 1st of April. We expect to get the final approvals very shortly indeed. That will add another very significant string to our bow in terms of product diversity, we will then have I think, everything you can possibly you think of and need to be the best corporate bank in the world.

I look at the outlook like Fred, I'm extremely nervous of forecasting precisely how we will do and I would emphasize really rather than focus on, which is the one tick, which is two ticks so to speak. I'm sure I've got one or two of those wrong, but I'm sure there will be a mixture and that's what gives me confidence. That because of the diversity, we're going to have as good a 2008 as you could expect and indeed better than anyone else.
Thank you. Back to you Fred.

Thanks Johnny. If I pick up the theme – and say I'm not going to explain you every single line. I'm not going to go through UK retail and commercial banking divisions. You can see very substantially the biggest part of the business, but I think if I leave you with a thought this is a linear progression there in UK corporate bank and in the retail division, linear and good and in the right -- very much in the right direction.

Touch on the US momentarily, now again I will do the same as Johnny and break out product-by-product, give you sense of what's been going on within the retail and commercial franchise. And just the underlying through the years at Citizens has continued to diversify away from just being a retail deposit taker who lent all money on to the US government. We made a considerable progress now over the last few years and that's reflected in actually some of the income growth that was achieved during 2007 where our commercial lending and deposits business, which is something we have been building up strongly moved ahead in double digits. In terms of income growth, our credit and debit card business moved ahead and sales of investment products rather along the lines that we do it in our UK branch network has moved ahead again in double digit terms.

Deposit margins have stabilized and indeed margins in Citizens have gone up from, I think, about 2.72 to 2.8. And if we take out one of last year the actual income growth in Citizens was about 4% this year, so quite a good point positive metric and a change of direction from where we've been heading in the last couple of years. Similar to Johnny's chart, there we are spread across 2006, 2007 -- spread across a range of products. In the interest of time I'm not going to go through all of them, – not very many of them, but just to echo the points I made a moment ago about commercial lending, commercial deposit taking down at that bottom there seeing good strong progress, continue to move forward in credit and debit cards, but obviously in personal lending coming back as we've reframed our risk appetite.

Outlook for next year, a bit like Johnny we could argue about an individual tick or two, a cross or two, but there are ticks under our crosses, I think it will remain a mixed picture in the United States going forward. There is no point in chasing risky business or unprofitable business and we've got no intention of doing so. There was enough there in the chart, we feel for us to be going on with particularly in the commercial lending arena. Whereas a result of the acquisition of business unit North America, we take a significant notching up in terms of numbers of customers in that segment. Something we do a lot of in the UK and as a segment, we feel very comfortable in it comprises as you can see from the chart, lending and deposit taking, not to mention the opportunity to sell money transmission and to sell the other products in Johnny's business. One of the big outstanding successes in Citizens has been the growth in selling quite labeled, simple derivative products to do interest rate protection, foreign currency protection to US mid-corporate and commercial customers and even down into the SME customer base.

Asia, a few moments on Asia. Quite interesting in Asia just to remind ourselves about the business we are talking about here is the retail and commercial piece but within Johnny's businesses is another chunk, which takes us to a place where you know, if we -- if our growth rates in Asia slow down by 50% next year, we will still pass through the billion pounds and profits generated in Asia, which is quite a move forward from where RBS was a little while ago and I wouldn't encourage you to think that we think our growth rates are going to slowdown in Asia next year, I think the reverse.

What's in that business? Quite an assortment, I think to be kind to it, a variety of branches and a variety of countries, but you'll see and remind yourselves of the slide about – earlier about GDP growth around the world. There is no shortage of GDP growth in the countries we are looking at. One of the challenges for us in this business though is that ABN have a vast and complex and rich infrastructure. On the one hand it's nice to be able to provide all of these products and have all of these capabilities in all of these in all these countries and in truth, I think it's a little unrealistic to think that we can achieve scale in all of these countries and all of these products.

So I think as we go forward, not withstanding our commitment and desire to grow in Asia, we'll be pruning back some of the product capabilities because it is very expensive to maintain and deploy under ground and I doubt whether it's the best use of our time and effort, trying get critical mass in all of these markets and all of these products. But the take away I would encourage you towards is that we have got the delivery mechanisms we need in the economies where we need it to deliver substantial growth in retail and commercial banking in Asia.

Still on the subject of outlook, well, how would I draw all that together? What would I ask you to hold in different views about the prospects for individual of these business lines. I am sure you'll have different views about individual countries and so on, but in thinking about -- or I think there is a high level take away from all of this. There are number of ingredients to the RBS outlook for 2008 and beyond.

The first ingredient, I think and I think by far and away that most important, we have existing organic momentum in our businesses and we don't have to start growing organically. We are growing organically and I think as you look at our divisional results you'll see that very clearly. We have a lot of new customers this year. "New" that is to say a lot of ABN AMRO customers are not new to the enlarge entity, but they are new to the RBS product range, they are new to the RBS business model.
